slides.title: Introduction to PolicyCenter Notes
slides.notes: Introduction to the concept of Notes in Guidewire PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our exploration of Notes in Guidewire PolicyCenter. Notes are a fundamental aspect of maintaining detailed records within the system, providing a way for users to document actions and decisions related to policies, accounts, and more. As developers, understanding how Notes interact with other entities in the data model is crucial for customizing and extending PolicyCenter effectively. Let’s dive into how Notes function and how you can leverage them in your implementations.

slides.title: Understanding Notes
slides.notes: Overview of what Notes are in the context of PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Notes in PolicyCenter serve as an essential means of capturing and communicating information across different parts of the system. Whether it’s a user adding context to a policy decision or a business rule logging an action, Notes help track and provide transparency. They are stored directly in the PolicyCenter database and can be created manually or programmatically using Gosu.

slides.title: Creating and Using Notes
slides.notes: Discuss how Notes are created and utilized in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Creating a Note in PolicyCenter can be as simple as a user entering text into a form, or as complex as a Gosu script triggering a Note creation automatically. You might configure Notes to capture specific interactions on a policy, like changes in coverage or updates to customer information. Understanding the practical applications of Notes helps in designing systems that facilitate effective communication and documentation.

slides.title: Notes vs. Documents
slides.originalNotes:
Notes
The common business case for a note is that an end user enters a detailed record of actions related to a policy, account , job, or contingency. Notes can also be created in business rules. In some cases it may make sense for a given business rule to create and attach a note to a job or account after an automatic action was been taken.

Notes and documents can have distinct functions in PolicyCenter- Notes are written in plain text, created by a user, or through Gosu, and stored only in the PolicyCenter database. Documents are more complex, and might have different Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions ( MIME) types such as PDF, Word, or Excel. Documents can be created and stored in either the PolicyCenter database or the document management system (third-party system). Both may use a template.

slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, it is important to distinguish between Notes and Documents. Notes are plain text entries stored only in the PolicyCenter database, ideal for quick, accessible records. Meanwhile, Documents can include various formats like PDF or Word, potentially stored in a separate document management system. This distinction helps guide when to use each feature, depending on the complexity and type of information you need to manage.

slides.title: Exploring Note Fields
slides.originalNotes:
Note fields
The fields in the note are the Topic, Subject, Security Level and the Text. Security Level Details: Is the note visible to everyone (unrestricted), internal users only (internal only), or only you, your supervisors, and people with permission to view sensitive notes (sensitive note).

slides.narration: Each Note in PolicyCenter contains fields such as Topic, Subject, Security Level, and Text. Understanding these fields is key for configuring how Notes are displayed and accessed. For instance, the Security Level determines note visibility, ensuring sensitive information is only accessible to authorized users. This feature is crucial for maintaining compliance and ensuring data privacy within your implementations.

slides.title: Security and Permissions
slides.notes: How security and permissions impact Note visibility and access.
slides.narration: When dealing with Notes, security and permissions play a significant role. Developers need to configure access controls based on business requirements, leveraging the Security Level field. This ensures that sensitive information is protected and accessible only to those with the right permissions, aligning with organizational policies on data security.

slides.title: Integration with Business Rules
slides.notes: Notes can be integrated into business rules for automated documentation.
slides.narration: Integrating Notes with business rules in PolicyCenter allows for automated documentation of system actions. For example, when a rule triggers an automatic policy update, a Note can be created to record this action, providing a clear audit trail. This capability is powerful for enhancing accountability and transparency in your workflows.

slides.title: Customizing Note Templates
slides.notes: Customization options for Note templates in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: PolicyCenter offers flexibility in customizing Note templates to fit specific business needs. You can define templates that standardize the information captured in Notes, ensuring consistency across records. This customization is particularly useful in organizations with complex documentation requirements or those that operate across different regions with varying regulations.

slides.notes: Recap of the key points about Notes and preview of the next lesson on Activities.
